import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

import warnings
warnings.filterwarnings("ignore")

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
%matplotlib inline
import plotly.offline as py

import warnings
warnings.filterwarnings("ignore")

import seaborn as sns
colors = ["#121212","#CF673A","#E4C56F","#97A37B","#BABABA","#E8DCCC"]
#sns.palplot(sns.color_palette(colors))

sns.countplot(x = df['Q1'].sort_values(),
              color=colors[2],
              edgecolor='white',
              linewidth=1.5,
              saturation=1.5)

plt.ylabel('Count', weight='semibold', fontname = 'Georgia')

source.13926a82:
import plotly.express as px

pie_col = ["#CF673A","#E4C56F","#97A37B","#BABABA","#E8DCCC","#1274A1"]

fig = px.pie(values= df['Q2'].value_counts().values, names= df['Q2'].value_counts().index)

fig.update_traces(hoverinfo='label+percent',
                  textinfo='value',
                  textfont_size=20,
                  marker=dict(colors=pie_col,
                              line=dict(color='#000000', width=1)))
fig.show()
source.c99356fd:
scale =[[0, '#E4C56F'],
             [0.5,'#455C4F'],
             [1.0, '#CF673A']]


settings = [ dict(
        type = 'choropleth',
        autocolorscale = False,
        colorscale = scale,
        showscale = True,
        locations = df.Q3.value_counts().index,
        z = df.Q3.value_counts().values,
        locationmode = 'country names',
        text = df.Q3.value_counts().index,
        marker = dict(
            line = dict(color = '#E4C56F', width = 0.5)),
            colorbar = dict(autotick = True, tickprefix = '', 
            title = 'Participants')
            )
       ]

layout = dict(
    title = 'In which country do you currently reside?',
    geo = dict(
        showframe = True,
        showocean = True,
        oceancolor = '#1274A1',
        projection = dict(
        type = 'orthographic',
            rotation = dict(
                    lon = 60,
                    lat = 10),
        ),
        lonaxis =  dict(
                showgrid = False,
                gridcolor = '#6e6d6d'
            ),
        lataxis = dict(
                showgrid = False,
                gridcolor = '#6e6d6d'
                )
            ),
        )
fig = dict(data=settings, layout=layout)
py.iplot(fig, validate=False, filename='worldmap')
source.92f84eff:
from textwrap import wrap

A = sns.countplot(x= df['Q4'],
              color=colors[2],
              edgecolor='white',
              linewidth=1.5,
              saturation=1.5)

labels = [ '\n'.join(wrap(l, 12)) for l in df['Q4'].unique()]

plt.ylabel('Count', weight='semibold', fontname = 'Georgia')
plt.xlabel('Education', weight='semibold', fontname = 'Georgia')

plt.suptitle('What is the highest level of formal education that you have attained or plan to attain within the next 2 years?', fontname = 'Georgia', weight='bold')

plt.tick_params(axis='x', which='major', labelsize=10)

A.set_xticklabels(labels, fontsize=10)

plt.show()
source.f3286ad5:
import plotly.graph_objs as go

edu = df['Q5'].value_counts()

trace = go.Scatter(
    x=edu.index,
    y=edu.values,
    mode='markers',
    marker=dict(
        sizemode = 'diameter',
        sizeref = 30,
        size = edu.values,
        color = edu.values,
        colorscale='Fall',
        showscale=True
    ),
)

layout = go.Layout(
    title='Select the title most similar to your current role (or most recent title if retired)'
)

data = [trace]
fig = go.Figure(data=data, layout=layout)
py.iplot(fig, filename="Current Role")
source.2f15f09e:
import plotly.graph_objs as go

edu = df['Q6'].value_counts()

trace = go.Scatter(
    x=edu.index,
    y=edu.values,
    mode='markers',
    marker=dict(
        sizemode = 'diameter',
        sizeref = 30,
        size = edu.values,
        #color = np.random.randn(500), #set color equal to a variable
        color = edu.values,
        colorscale='Fall',
        showscale=True
    ),
)

layout = go.Layout(
    title='For how many years have you been writing code and/or programming?'
)

data = [trace]
fig = go.Figure(data=data, layout=layout)
py.iplot(fig, filename="LearningDataScience")
source.4307a021:
def ques_title(ques):
    title = questions.filter(regex = ques)[0].split("?")[0]+'?'
    return title
ques_title('Q7')
source.8bc6c427:
def plot(ques,lab, fsize = (16, 9)):
    a = df.filter(regex = ques)
    answer_desc = a.describe()
    answergot = answer_desc.loc[['top', 'count']].T
    answergot = answergot.set_index('top')
    answergot = answergot.sort_values(by="count", ascending = False)
    
    plt.figure(figsize = fsize)
    A = sns.barplot(data = answergot,
                 x='count',
                 y = answergot.index,
              color=colors[2],
              edgecolor='white',
              linewidth=1.5,
              saturation=1.5)
    
    plt.xlabel('Count', weight='semibold', fontname = 'Georgia')
    plt.ylabel(lab, weight='semibold', fontname = 'Georgia')
    plt.suptitle(ques_title(ques), fontname = 'Georgia', weight='bold')
    
    A.bar_label(A.containers[0])
    
    plt.show
source.e160551d:
def plotcount(ques,lab):
    A = sns.countplot(y= df[ques],
              color=colors[2],
              edgecolor='white',
              linewidth=1.5,
              saturation=1.5)
    
    #from textwrap import wrap
    #labels = [ '\n'.join(wrap(l, 12)) for l in df[ques].unique()]
    #plt.tick_params(axis='x', which='major', labelsize=10)

    

    plt.xlabel('Count', weight='semibold', fontname = 'Georgia')
    plt.ylabel(lab, weight='semibold', fontname = 'Georgia')
    plt.suptitle(ques_title(ques), fontname = 'Georgia', weight='bold')
    A.bar_label(A.containers[0])
    
    #A.set_xticklabels(labels, fontsize=10)
    
    plt.show

source.b95858c6:
<div style="display:fill;
            border-radius: False;
            border-style: solid;
            border-color:#CF673A;
            border-style: false;
            border-width: 3px;
            color:#121212;
            font-size:15px;
            font-family: Georgia;
            background-color:#E4C56F;
            text-align:center;
            letter-spacing:0.5px;
            padding: 0.7em;
            text-align:left">
    
**About Competition**

 tell a data story about a subset of the data science community represented in this survey, through a combination of both narrative text and data exploration. A “story” could be defined any number of ways, and that’s deliberate. The challenge is to deeply explore (through data) the impact, priorities, or concerns of a specific group of data science and machine learning practitioners. That group can be defined in the macro (for example: anyone who does most of their coding in Python) or the micro (for example: female data science students studying machine learning in masters programs). 
    
*This is an opportunity to be creative and tell the story of a community you identify with or are passionate about!*

source.cfcb133c: Introduction: Hey! It's a great opportunity to get involved in the best and coolest community of Data Scientists, Statisticians, Coders, and Creatives. I look up to many people here and learned a lot in the past few months and want to get involved in the most creative competition of Kaggle's 5th Survey. I will try to do my best here with creativity and analysis. I am working on ideas on how I am going to tell the story, but I started with my favorite season of the year autumn so my colors are inspired by it. I will keep updating the notebook with new Ideas and hopefully will complete it before submission. Let's get started and Enjoy!
source.6d12dd6f:
Data Definition
Number Question
Q1 What is your age (# years)?
Q2 What is your gender?
Q3 In which country do you currently reside?
Q4 What is the highest level of formal education that you have attained or plan to attain within the next 2 years?
Q5 Select the title most similar to your current role (or most recent title if retired)
Q6 For how many years have you been writing code and/or programming?
Q7 What programming languages do you use on a regular basis?
Q8 What programming language would you recommend an aspiring data scientist to learn first?
Q9 Which of the following integrated development environments (IDE's) do you use on a regular basis?
Q10 Which of the following hosted notebook products do you use on a regular basis?
Q11 What type of computing platform do you use most often for your data science projects?
Q12 Which types of specialized hardware do you use on a regular basis?
Q13 Approximately how many times have you used a TPU
Q14 What data visualization libraries or tools do you use on a regular basis?
Q15 For how many years have you used machine learning methods?
Q16 Which of the following machine learning frameworks do you use on a regular basis?
Q17 Which of the following ML algorithms do you use on a regular basis?
Q18 Which categories of computer vision methods do you use on a regular basis?
Q19 Which of the following natural language processing (NLP) methods do you use on a regular basis?
Q20 In what industry is your current employer/contract (or your most recent employer if retired)?
Q21 What is the size of the company where you are employed?
Q22 Approximately how many individuals are responsible for data science workloads at your place of business?
Q23 Does your current employer incorporate machine learning methods into their business?
Q24 Select any activities that make up an important part of your role at work.
Q25 What is your current yearly compensation?
Q26 Approximately how much money have you (or your team) spent on machine learning and/or cloud computing services at home (or at work) in the past 5 years?
Q27 Which of the following cloud computing platforms do you use on a regular basis?
Q28 Of the cloud platforms that you are familiar with, which has the best developer experience (most enjoyable to use)?
Q29 Do you use any of the following cloud computing products on a regular basis?
Q30 Do you use any of the following data storage products on a regular basis?
Q31 In the next 2 years, do you hope to become more familiar with any of these managed machine learning products?
Q32 Which of the following big data products (relational databases, data warehouses, data lakes, or similar) do you hope to become more familiar with in the next 2 years?
Q33 Which of the following big data products (relational database, data warehouse, data lake, or similar) do you use most often?
Q34 Which of the following business intelligence tools do you hope to become more familiar with in the next 2 years?
Q35 Which of the following business intelligence tools do you use most often?
Q36 Which categories of automated machine learning tools (or partial AutoML tools) do you hope to become more familiar with in the next 2 years?
Q37 Which specific automated machine learning tools (or partial AutoML tools) do you hope to become more familiar with in the next 2 years?
Q38 In the next 2 years, do you hope to become more familiar with any of these tools for managing ML experiments?
Q39 Where do you publicly share your data analysis or machine learning applications?
Q40 On which platforms have you begun or completed data science courses?
Q41 What is the primary tool that you use at work or school to analyze data?
Q42 Who/what are your favorite media sources that report on data science topics?
